Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of RPD's Internal Flight Alternative (IFA) analysis
Outcome: Judicial review allowed; case remanded for reconsideration
Basis_of_Claim: Fear of persecution by Qaddafi regime supporters
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Failure to assess IFA conditions for minor child
Inadequate consideration of psychological evidence
Application_Error: Failure to assess country conditions and impact on minor child
Legal_Standard: Two-prong IFA test: no serious possibility of persecution and reasonable relocation conditions
Decision_Outcome: RPD decision found unreasonable; remanded to different panel

Legal_Issue: Well-founded fear of persecution, Internal Flight Alternative (IFA)
Outcome: Application dismissed
Credibility_Assessment: RPD found insufficient evidence of credible threats outside home area
Evidence_Type: Lack of evidence regarding adverse conditions in Chittagong
Basis_of_Claim: Fear of persecution due to political activities
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Existence of reasonable Internal Flight Alternative
Legal_Standard: Well-founded fear of persecution, Reasonable expectation of relocation
Application_Factor: Political opinion as grounds for claim
Decision_Outcome: No error found in RPD's decision

Outcome: Judicial review allowed, decision remitted for reassessment
Credibility_Assessment: Mr. Cartagena faced credible threats from Mara 18
Evidence_Type: Country condition reports on El Salvador
Basis_of_Claim: Fear of persecution by non-state actor (gang) in El Salvador
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Viable internal flight alternative must be both factually possible and reasonable considering claimant's circumstances
Application_Error: Failure to properly assess reasonableness of IFA in light of claimant’s vulnerabilities
Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness standard under the Dunsmuir framework
Evidence_Ignored: Lack of familial or community support
High crime and unemployment rates in proposed IFA locations
Application_Factor: Security conditions in proposed IFA locations
Decision_Outcome: Remitted to a differently constituted panel for reconsideration

Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 96 and Section 147 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed fear of persecution based on membership in a minority clan in Somalia; Officer found general insecurity rather than persecution and cited Internal Flight Alternative (IFA) in Somaliland; evidence indicated Somaliland was unsafe for the applicant
Claimant_Status: Refugee claimant under Convention refugee abroad class and country of asylum class
Procedural_Issue: Failure to properly assess well-founded fear of persecution and viability of IFA
Evidence_Used: Evidence of clan-based persecution, conditions in Somaliland, lack of state protection
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient consideration of evidence showing risks in Somaliland
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim rejected by immigration officer
Outcome: Judicial review granted; decision found unreasonable and legally erroneous
Remedy_Sought: Redetermination of refugee claim by another immigration officer
Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution under Section 96; country of asylum class under Section 147
Decision_Rationale: Officer unreasonably concluded no persecution and viable IFA despite evidence of clan-based risk and unsafe conditions in Somaliland
Authority_Responsible: Immigration Officer, Immigration and Refugee Board

Legal_Issue: Existence of an internal flight alternative (IFA)
Outcome: Judicial review dismissed
Credibility_Assessment: Applicant misrepresented her situation upon entering Canada
Evidence_Type: Lack of evidence regarding inability to relocate within Hungary
Legal_Provision: Section 97(1) of IRPA - Internal flight alternative
Basis_of_Claim: Domestic violence and lack of state protection in Hungary
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Applicant's failure to prove no reasonable IFA exists
Legal_Standard: Burden on applicant to demonstrate no viable IFA
Application_Factor: Fear of deportation and spousal violence

Legal_Provision_Violated: Failure to assess under country of asylum class criteria
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, Section 115(2) - Country of Asylum Class
Application_Facts: Applicants are Hazara from Afghanistan; claimed discrimination and risk due to ongoing conflict
Procedural_Issue: Officer failed to consider country of asylum class eligibility
Evidence_Used: Conditions in Afghanistan, Hazara persecution, conflict-related risks
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of assessment on serious personal effects from conflict
Decision_Outcome: Application refused based solely on Convention refugee criteria
Outcome: Judicial review granted; decision set aside
Remedy_Sought: Reconsideration of application under correct legal framework
Legal_Standard_Applied: Convention refugee and country of asylum class criteria
Decision_Rationale: Officer committed a reviewable error by not evaluating country of asylum class eligibility despite evidence of serious personal effects from conflict

Legal_Issue: Is the Immigration and Refugee Board's decision regarding the internal flight alternative (IFA) in Abuja reasonable given the applicant's circumstances?
Outcome: The application for judicial review is allowed, and the matter is sent back to a newly constituted Board for redetermination.
Legal_Provision: Section 72 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Basis_of_Claim: Refugee protection due to FGM, abuse, trafficking, lack of family support, and psychological trauma
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Applicant's vulnerabilities including trauma, illiteracy, lack of education, and no family support
Evidence_Ignored: Psychological state, personal vulnerabilities, lack of support systems
Legal_Standard: An IFA must be viable and reasonable for the specific claimant considering their psychological and personal situation
Application_Factor: Severe trauma, FGM, forced prostitution, human trafficking, disownment

Legal_Issue: Is the Immigration and Refugee Board's decision regarding the internal flight alternative (IFA) in Abuja reasonable given the applicant's circumstances?
Legal_Rule: An IFA must be viable and reasonable for the specific claimant considering their personal situation
Grounds_for_Claim: Fear of persecution, trauma, human trafficking, FGM threats
Key_Evidence_Considered: History of trafficking, forced prostitution, psychological stress, lack of education and family support
Outcome: Application allowed; remanded for redetermination
Legal_Provision: Section 72 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act

Violation_Type: Failure to recognize viability of internal flight alternative for vulnerable claimant
Application_Facts: Applicant suffered human trafficking, FGM threats, disownment, illiteracy, and emotional/physical stress
Procedural_Issue: Inadequate consideration of vulnerabilities in IFA assessment
Evidence_Used: Personal history of abuse, lack of support, psychological condition
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Board failed to consider applicant’s vulnerabilities
Outcome: Remanded for redetermination
Decision_Rationale: IFA not viable due to claimant’s extreme vulnerability

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Outcome: Application allowed; remanded for redetermination
Grounds_for_Claim: Past trauma, forcible confinement, abuse, fear of persecution
Risk_Factor: Trauma, illiteracy, lack of family support
Legal_Provision: Section 72 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
State_Protection_Adequacy: Insufficient protection from harm in Nigeria
Risk_Nature: Persecution based on gender and past victimization
Victim_Basis: Gender, past exploitation, lack of support

Victim_Status: Female refugee claimant with history of trauma
Risk_Assessment: High risk if returned to Nigeria
Targeted_Victimization: Women subjected to sexual exploitation and FGM
Targeted_Individual: Female survivor of trafficking and abuse
Evidence_Sufficiency: Sufficient evidence of trauma and vulnerability

Violation_Type: Failure to establish safe Internal Flight Alternative
Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Section 96, Section 97
Governing_Law: IRPA, Canadian jurisprudence on IFA and refugee protection
Application_Facts: Applicant fled Mexico due to domestic abuse and credible threats from ex-husband; fears persecution if returned, especially regarding custody of children
Procedural_Issue: Board imposed unreasonable condition requiring abandonment of custody rights as part of IFA
Evidence_Used: Credible testimony of applicant, documented history of domestic violence, threats from ex-husband
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Board failed to adequately consider evidence of ongoing risk and lack of state protection in Mexico
Credibility_Assessment: Applicant found credible by the Board
Decision_Outcome: Board initially denied refugee protection based on existence of IFA
Outcome: Judicial review successful; decision set aside
Remedy_Sought: New determination by a different panel
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness of IFA under established jurisprudence
Decision_Rationale: IFA determination unreasonable as it required claimant to forgo custody rights; ignored credible risk of persecution
Authority_Responsible: Refugee Protection Division of the Immigration and Refugee Board

Dispute_Type: Judicial review of visa officer's decision
Legal_Issue: Assessment of applicant's work experience under Canadian Experience Class
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations, Section 87.1 (Canadian Experience Class), Section 80(3) (Federal Skilled Worker Class)
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed, no costs awarded
Credibility_Assessment: Applicant provided conflicting information about job duties; explanations did not resolve inconsistencies
Evidence_Type: Employer confirmation of duties, applicant's statements
Basis_of_Claim: Claimed skilled work experience under NOC requirements
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Discrepancies between stated duties and employer-confirmed duties
Application_Error: Inconsistent reporting of job duties by applicant
Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness standard applied to officer's decision
Legal_Standard: Reasonableness of administrative decision, procedural fairness
Application_Factor: Work experience assessment under Canadian Experience Class
Document_Fraud: No explicit finding of document fraud, but false or inconsistent statements identified

Legal_Issue: Whether the Board erred in determining that the applicants were not Convention refugees or persons in need of protection
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed
Legal_Provision: Section 97 (protection from torture, risk to life, etc.)
Key_Factor_in_Determination: No well-founded fear of persecution on Convention grounds
Incidents not rising to level of persecution
LTTE extortion tied to general country conditions
Application_Error: Alleged error in assessing persecution and future risk

Crimes.Crime_Name: Marriage Fraud under Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Dispute over whether Mr. Liang was a legitimate businessman or a criminal fleeing prosecution
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the applicant, Mr. Liang, should be excluded as a refugee under Article 1F(b) due to serious reasons for considering he committed a non-political crime

Crimes.Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed; Mr. Liang excluded as a refugee
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: The board found Mr. Liang's story implausible and favored the Minister's evidence

Crimes.Crime_Name: Misrepresentation under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Legal_Issue: Whether the Officer breached procedural fairness or made an unreasonable decision
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed
Credibility_Assessment: Applicant failed to provide adequate response; submitted documents lacked authenticity
Legal_Provision: Section related to misrepresentation in immigration applications
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Failure to substantiate document authenticity after fairness letter
Application_Error: Misrepresentation of property ownership through suspicious documents
Application_Factor: Submission of supporting documents for financial standing
Decision_Outcome: Applicant found inadmissible for two years
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness for merits, correctness for procedural fairness
Document_Fraud: Property certificates suspected and treated as inauthentic

Crimes.Crime_Name: Submitting inauthentic documents for an immigration application
Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act – authenticity requirements
Application_Facts: Applicant submitted property certificates that were deemed inauthentic
Procedural_Issue: Officer did not disclose underlying evidence of fraud but issued a fairness letter
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Applicant failed to provide verifiable proof of ownership
Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's credibility undermined due to lack of verification
Outcome: Applicant found inadmissible for two years
Standard_of_Review: Correctness for procedural fairness, reasonableness for decision merits
Decision_Rationale: Applicant was given opportunity to respond but failed to provide credible evidence

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of removal order
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the applicant met the three-part test for a stay of removal
Crimes.Outcome: Motion for stay of removal denied
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's arguments were speculative and lacked credibility
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Immigration applications, family ties, legal status history
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Pending immigration applications and family separation
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Failure to demonstrate serious issue to be tried
Crimes.Application_Error: Speculative arguments and lack of legal basis
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Serious issue, irreparable harm, balance of convenience
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Emotional hardship due to family separation not considered irreparable harm
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Three-part test for stay of removal
Crimes.Application_Factor: History of non-compliance with immigration obligations
Crimes.Authority: Minister of Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Misrepresentation in border or immigration documents

Crimes.Violation_Type: Unauthorized stay in Canada beyond visa validity

Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction over immigration decisions
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Immigration records, application history, status documentation
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of proof of irreparable harm or serious issue
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's claims deemed insufficiently supported
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Stay of removal pending immigration applications
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Three-part test: serious issue, irreparable harm, balance of convenience
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Obligation to enforce removal orders promptly under IRPA
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Canada Border Services Agency (CBSA), Minister of IRCC

Crimes.Crime_Name: Possibly Warrant for Armed Robbery (not confirmed in Canada).

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to demonstrate establishment in home country

Crimes.Evidence_Type: Lack of documentation showing strong residential, economic, or familial ties to Pakistan or UAE
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Applicant did not meet burden of proving intent to leave Canada after authorized stay
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of establishment in home country and uncertainty regarding return to UAE

Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None found; officer considered available information
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Procedural fairness assessed on correctness, decision reviewed for reasonableness
Crimes.Application_Factor: Economic incentives not determinative but considered as part of overall assessment
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness for decision, correctness for procedural fairness

Crimes.Crime_Name: Work Permit Refusal under Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial Review
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness and procedural fairness of visa officer's decision

Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Sadiq failed to provide sufficient evidence of ties to Pakistan or ability to return to UAE
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Lack of proof of permanent status in UAE or strong connections to Pakistan
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Officer not satisfied applicant would leave Canada by end of authorized stay

Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to demonstrate durable ties outside Canada

Crimes.Application_Factor: Residential instability and absence of binding obligations abroad

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial Review
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether economic incentives were overemphasized and if procedural fairness was breached

Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Concerns about intent to remain in Canada due to stronger economic opportunities

Crimes.Application_Error: Did not adequately rebut assumption of intent to overstay

Crimes.Application_Factor: Potential for abuse of temporary status for economic benefit

Legal_Issue: Whether the Board's decision to reject Mr. Pineda's refugee claim based on lack of credibility is reasonable
Governing_Law: Rule: The Board can reject a claim if it finds significant inconsistencies and omissions in the claimant's testimony and Personal Information Form (PIF)
Outcome: The Court found the Board's credibility assessment reasonable and dismissed the application for judicial review
Credibility_Assessment: Mr. Pineda's testimony, PIF, and supporting affidavit contained contradictions regarding key events, including the death of Benedicto and threats against his family. Significant omissions, like the death of his grandmother, further undermined his credibility
Basis_of_Claim: Persecution by his former employer in Guatemala
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Inconsistent evidence and significant inconsistencies and omissions in testimony and documentation
Application_Error: Inconsistencies and omissions in the Personal Information Form and testimony
Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness of the Board's credibility assessment
Decision_Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed; Board's decision upheld
Document_Fraud: Contradictions and omissions in PIF and affidavit may indicate false statements

Legal_Issue: Whether the officer erred in assessing language proficiency beyond AEO specifications
Outcome: Judicial review allowed, application remitted for redetermination
Basis_of_Claim: Officer imposed additional language requirements not specified in AEO
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Officer exceeded AEO language requirements by assessing reading and writing skills
Application_Error: Imposing higher language proficiency standard than required
Assessment_Standard: Basic English oral proficiency as per AEO
Evidence_Ignored: Applicant's demonstrated oral proficiency meeting AEO standard
Legal_Standard: Reasonableness and correctness standards in judicial review
Decision_Outcome: Permanent residence application denied initially, decision set aside on review

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: IRPA and IRPR - Failure to comply with authorized stay conditions

Crimes.Legal_Standard: Applicant bears burden to prove admissibility and intent to depart

Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Refusal upheld – insufficient demonstration of intent to return

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial Review of Visa Denial
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Alleged inadequate reasons, procedural unfairness, or misapprehension of evidence
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), subsection 72(1)
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: No adverse credibility finding; concerns based on lack of evidence, not dishonesty
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Allegation that decision lacked transparency and violated fairness
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Absence of extrinsic evidence negated need for interview or further disclosure
Crimes.Application_Error: No error found in decision-making process
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None identified – court found full consideration of submitted materials
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Procedural fairness and adequacy of reasons in administrative decisions
Crimes.Application_Factor: Repeated applications with similar deficiencies

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Permanent residence application rejection
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the IAD erred in concluding that Mr. Malhi was not a member of the family class due to non-genuine marriage
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, subsection 72(1); Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations, section 4
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Mr. Malhi lacked knowledge about Ms. Froment’s children and personal background
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 4 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Marriage must be genuine and not primarily for immigration purposes
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of knowledge about spouse's children
Significant age difference
Language and religious differences
Crimes.Application_Error: Alleged incorrect assessment of marriage genuineness
Crimes.Application_Factor: Family class eligibility based on spousal relationship

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Permanent residence application rejection based on alleged insincere marriage
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the IAD erred in finding the marriage not genuine for immigration purposes
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, subsection 72(1); Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Mr. Malhi demonstrated insufficient knowledge of Ms. Froment’s personal history and children
Evidence_Type: Lack of familiarity with personal details
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations – genuine marriage requirement
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Marriage must be authentic and not entered primarily for immigration benefits
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of knowledge of spouse's children
Cultural and linguistic gaps
Personal unfamiliarity
Crimes.Application_Factor: Eligibility under family class via spousal sponsorship
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: IAD decision upheld; no intervention warranted

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Immigration sponsorship appeal
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the relationship between the applicant and his wife was genuine
Crimes.Governing_Law: Section 4 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Judicial review of Immigration Appeal Division decision
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Hotel bills, photos, frequent communications, presence of a child together
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On the applicant to demonstrate genuineness of marriage
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Contradictions in testimony noted but outweighed by supporting evidence
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Marriage must be genuine; not entered for immigration benefits
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Refusal of spouse’s permanent residence application based on alleged non-genuine relationship
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act and Regulations
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Doubted authenticity of marriage based on inconsistencies and age difference
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review allowed; case remanded to another visa officer
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 4, Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Spousal sponsorship based on alleged sham marriage
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the marriage was genuine or primarily for immigration purposes
Crimes.Governing_Law: Section 4 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Crimes.Outcome: Original decision set aside; remanded for redetermination
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Testimonies contained contradictions but supported by birth of child and ongoing contact
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 4, Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Marriage entered into for immigration advantage
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Presence of child, frequency of communication, cultural context
Crimes.Decision_Maker: Immigration Appeal Division, reviewed by Federal Court
Crimes.Application_Error: Focus on irrelevant factors such as age difference and pre-marriage knowledge
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Evidence of shared life and interdependence
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Genuine marital relationship required for sponsorship
Crimes.Application_Factor: Assessment of exclusivity, intimacy, interdependence, permanence, societal perception

Legal_Issue: Were the applicants denied procedural fairness by not being notified of a request for further evidence?
Outcome: The applicants were denied procedural fairness due to the misdirected request, and the matter is remitted for redetermination.
Evidence_Type: Request for information regarding an internal flight alternative (IFA)
Basis_of_Claim: Failure to provide applicants with direct notification of request for further evidence
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Applicants were unaware of the request for evidence until after the decision was made
Proceeding_Type: Judicial review application in Federal Court
Application_Error: Request for further evidence sent to former lawyer who did not forward it
Evidence_Ignored: Request for information on IFA not received by applicants
Legal_Standard: Procedural fairness requires providing affected individuals the opportunity to present their views and evidence fully
Application_Factor: Opportunity to respond to evidence requests
Decision_Outcome: Court allowed the application, set aside the original decision, and ordered a redetermination

Legal_Issue: Whether the Federal Court has jurisdiction over a claim of misrepresentation by federal fisheries officers leading to the surrender of a fishing license
Governing_Law: Section 17(5)(b) of the Federal Court Act
Outcome: Court affirmed jurisdiction and dismissed the defendants' application to dismiss
Legal_Provision: Section 17(5)(b) of the Federal Court Act
Basis_of_Claim: Alleged misrepresentation by fisheries officers about fishing regulations inducing the surrender of a license
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Whether the claim depended on federal law under the Fisheries Act
Proceeding_Type: Application to dismiss for lack of jurisdiction
Legal_Standard: Jurisdiction under Section 17(5)(b) of the Federal Court Act
Application_Factor: Claim involved persons acting outside their duties as Crown officers
Decision_Outcome: Jurisdiction upheld; application to dismiss denied

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee status determination
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Adequacy of state protection in St. Lucia
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant feared retaliation and police corruption, but Board found state protection available
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Testimony regarding domestic abuse and police ineffectiveness
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Obligation to seek or rebut availability of state protection before claiming refugee status
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Fear of domestic abuse and lack of effective state protection
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Availability of state protection despite imperfections
Crimes.Application_Factor: Failure to report abuse to authorities

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee status determination based on state protection
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Adequacy of state protection in St. Lucia
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Applicant’s fear due to abuser’s criminal connections and police corruption
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On claimant to demonstrate lack of effective state protection
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Fear of retaliation outweighed by availability of state protection
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Claimant must attempt to access state protection or show it is unavailable
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Domestic abuse and fear of police corruption
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Abuser’s known involvement in drug dealing and police knowledge
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Fear of reporting due to corrupt and ineffective police
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Personal testimony and country condition evidence

Crimes.Victim_Status: Female survivor of intimate partner violence
Crimes.Perpetrator_Type: Intimate partner involved in drug dealing
Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: State institutions exist but perceived as ineffective
Crimes.Prior_Criminality: Perpetrator known to police for drug-related offenses
Crimes.Criminality_Severity: High (ongoing abuse and threats to life)
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Targeted due to relationship with perpetrator
Crimes.Targeted_Victimization: Yes, based on gender and relationship
Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Sufficient to establish abuse, insufficient to prove lack of state protection
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Personal testimony, context of domestic violence in St. Lucia
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Believable account but failed to engage state protection
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 97(1) of IRPA – need to seek or rebut state protection

Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Fear of police corruption and retaliation
Crimes.Threat_Source: Former partner with law enforcement awareness
Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Credible evidence of abuse, but not of systemic failure
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Affidavit, narrative of abuse, country condition reports
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Credible but insufficient to overcome presumption of state protection
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA and jurisprudence on internal flight alternative and state protection

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Interpretation of regulatory provision
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the IAD erred in interpreting 'time of application' under paragraph 117(9)(d) of the Regulations
Crimes.Governing_Law: Paragraph 117(9)(d) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations

Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Failure to declare daughter’s birth during immigration process
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Ongoing obligation to update application post-initial filing
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to declare dependent after birth
Crimes.Application_Factor: Timing of disclosure relative to application process
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Error in law found, remitted for reconsideration

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to declare dependants under Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Interpretation of 'at the time of application'
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the IAD erred in limiting 'application' to initial submission
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations (IRPR), paragraph 117(9)(d)
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Timing of declaration of child's birth
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: IAD decision set aside, remanded for reevaluation
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to disclose all dependants
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Obligation to disclose all family members throughout application process
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Failure to declare newborn daughter before obtaining permanent residency
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Immigration forms, date of child's birth, timing of disclosure
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act and Regulations
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Official immigration documents, birth certificate

Dispute_Type: Judicial review of refugee protection decision
Legal_Issue: Procedural fairness and credibility assessment in refugee claim
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed
Credibility_Assessment: Inconsistencies in Mejia's testimony supported the Board’s credibility findings
Basis_of_Claim: Fear of persecution due to witnessing a murder
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of credible evidence, failure to object during hearing
Application_Error: No objection raised during the hearing regarding procedural fairness
Application_Factor: Fairness of procedure, reasonableness of decision
Decision_Outcome: Upheld Board’s denial of refugee protection

Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant overstayed visa after deportation from the U.S. and sought protection in Canada based on alleged risks in Nigeria.
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Inadmissible due to overstaying and prior deportation
Evidence_Used: Documents alleging risk from stepmother in Nigeria
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Credibility not questioned; issue was sufficiency of evidence
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Permanent Residence via PRRA and H&C grounds
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Insufficient evidence to establish personalized risk or humanitarian and compassionate grounds

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refusal of PRRA and H&C applications

Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: No adverse credibility findings; focus on evidentiary sufficiency
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Risk upon return to Nigeria due to familial conflict
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of sufficient, probative evidence of personalized risk
Crimes.Application_Factor: Evaluation of risk and humanitarian considerations

Crimes.Criminality_Severity: Not assessed due to insufficient evidence of violence
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Officer found insufficient evidence of ongoing or targeted risk
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Alleged familial conflict and potential harm
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Not discredited, but low probative value
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: No negative assessment; deficiency in proof, not truthfulness

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refusal of PRRA and H&C applications
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Assessment of authenticity and weight of documentary evidence
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: No explicit finding of forgery; documents given low weight due to lack of probative value

Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Low probative value of submitted documents

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refusal of PRRA and H&C applications

Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: No adverse credibility finding; evidence deemed insufficient rather than false
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Risk due to family disputes and best interests of children
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of linkage between personal circumstances and country conditions
Crimes.Application_Factor: Subjective and objective risk factors, children’s best interests

Crimes.Crime_Name: Concealment or amputation of public records under the Access to Information Act
Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Administrative grievance regarding access to information and procedural fairness
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Involved: Section 24(1)(a) of the Public Servants Disclosure Protection Act (PSDP Act)
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged concealment and fabrication of public records
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Public Servants Disclosure Protection Act (PSDP Act), Access to Information Act
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: PSIC's decision upheld as reasonable and procedurally fair
Crimes.Institutional_Action: PSIC refused to investigate based on prior handling by OIC
Crimes.Government_Body_or_Authority: Public Sector Integrity Commissioner (PSIC), Office of the Information Commissioner (OIC)
Crimes.Individual_Status_or_Claim: Applicant seeking investigation into government conduct
Crimes.Credibility: Applicant provided written arguments; credibility not formally challenged
Crimes.Victim_Basis: Public interest in transparency and accountability

Crimes.Crime_Name: Fabrication of evidence to affect tribunal proceedings
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Administrative dispute over disclosure and investigation refusal
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether PSIC erred in refusing to investigate under s. 24(1) of PSDP Act
Crimes.Governing_Law: Public Servants Disclosure Protection Act (PSDP Act)
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Prior OIC findings considered sufficient; no new investigation warranted
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to show unreasonableness or breach of fairness
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Applicant allowed to submit written arguments; opportunity provided
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Section 24(1) of PSDP Act allows refusal if matter adequately dealt with elsewhere
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness, with consideration of procedural fairness
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Allegation of fabrication of evidence in tribunal context
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Claim dismissed; PSIC decision found reasonable
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: OIC's prior assessment and applicant's submissions
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Public Servants Disclosure Protection Act (PSDP Act)
Crimes.Defendant_Response: PSIC asserted discretion under s. 24(1) and referred to OIC process
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Documentary submissions, prior OIC findings
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Investigation into alleged misconduct and legal advice

Legal_Issue: Registrability of the trademark 'Deli Snack' under the Trade-marks Act
Evidence_Assessment: Assessment of consumer perception and contextual use of the term 'Deli Snack'
Burden_of_Proof: On the applicant (Neptune S.A.) to demonstrate registrability
Legal_Rule: A trademark is not registrable if it is clearly descriptive or deceptively misdescriptive of the character or quality of the goods
Grounds_for_Claim: The trademark 'Deli Snack' is descriptive of seafood-based snacks
Outcome_on_Merits: The claim for registration was rejected on substantive grounds
Key_Evidence_Considered: Meaning and common usage of 'Deli Snack' in relation to delicatessen snack foods
Legal_Framework: Canadian Trade-marks Act and administrative review principles
Defendant_Response: Registrar opposed registration on grounds of descriptiveness
Evidence_Type: Descriptive meaning of words, market context, consumer understanding
Outcome: Appeal dismissed; registration denied

Legal_Provision_Violated: s. 87(3) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, s. 72(1)
Application_Facts: Applicant had family support and provincial endorsement but failed to demonstrate financial self-sufficiency over two years as a visitor in Canada
Residency_Compliance: Complied with temporary stay as a visitor
Evidence_Used: Nomination certificate, Officer's assessment of motivation and initiative, duration and nature of stay in Canada
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of evidence showing initiative or motivation toward economic establishment
Credibility_Assessment: Officer found applicant lacked motivation; concurring officer agreed
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed
Decision_Rationale: Officer reasonably concluded applicant unlikely to become economically established despite nomination; decision within acceptable range of outcomes

Legal_Issue: Procedural fairness in visa application assessment
Evidence_Assessment: Insufficient evidence of full-time student status and dependent child relationship
Credibility_Factor: Concerns raised by visa officer regarding genuineness of claims
Legal_Rule: Applicants must provide all relevant information; visa officers not required to engage in dialogue unless credibility concerns arise
Key_Evidence_Considered: Documentation related to student status and dependency
Legal_Framework: Canadian immigration law, procedural fairness principles
Defendant_Response: Visa officer provided general notice but did not initiate further dialogue
Remedy_Requested: Judicial intervention to overturn visa denial
Outcome: Court dismissed judicial review, upheld visa officer's decision
Legal_Provision: Section 16(1) of IRPA – Temporary Resident Visa requirements

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with voluntary departure orders
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) subsection 25(1)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicants overstayed visitor status, applied for permanent residence on humanitarian and compassionate (H&C) grounds, had minor child Min Ji under 18 at time of application
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Applicants without valid status in Canada
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant – overstayed visa and failed to depart voluntarily
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Inadequate consideration of H&C factors, particularly best interests of the child
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Establishment in Canada, family ties, children’s integration
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Officer underestimated hardships and dismissed establishment in Canada
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not explicitly challenged
Crimes.Outcome: Decision quashed, matter remanded for reconsideration
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Permanent residence on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Judicial review and re-assessment of H&C application
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Humanitarian and compassionate considerations under IRPA s. 25(1)
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Failure to properly assess best interests of Min Ji rendered decision unreasonable
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Visa Officer, Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refusal of humanitarian and compassionate application
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Breach of procedural fairness and incorrect application of H&C tests, including best interests of the child
Crimes.Outcome: Decision quashed, case returned for reconsideration
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not found to be an issue
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Residential history, employment records, children’s education in Canada
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Humanitarian and compassionate grounds due to long-term residence and family establishment
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Best interests of minor child Min Ji
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to adequately analyze best interests of the child and disproportionate hardship
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Humanitarian and compassionate considerations under s. 25(1) IRPA
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Extent of applicants’ establishment in Canada and impact on children
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Reasonableness standard applied to officer’s decision
Crimes.Application_Factor: Long-term illegal stay since 2001, unauthorized work, integration of children

Crimes.Violation_Type: Unlawful presence in Canada beyond authorized period
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) subsection 25(1)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicants entered as visitors, remained since 2001, established lives, applied for permanent residence on H&C grounds
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant – overstayed visas and remained without authorization
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Insufficient analysis of best interests of Min Ji, who was under 18 at time of application
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Length of stay, community ties, children’s education and integration
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Officer inadequately assessed hardships and best interests of the child
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: No adverse credibility finding
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Permanent residency based on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Judicial review and re-determination with proper H&C assessment
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Humanitarian and compassionate considerations under IRPA s. 25(1)
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Unreasonable failure to consider Min Ji's best interests

Violation_Type: Failure to prove unavailability of state protection
Legal_Provision_Violated: Paragraph 96(2) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA)
Application_Facts: Family fled Mexico after alleged threats from local criminals; claimed lack of state protection; did not report incidents to police
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of Refugee Protection Division (RPD) decision
Evidence_Used: Applicants' claims of criminal threats, lack of engagement with Mexican authorities
Evidentiary_Deficiency: No evidence showing that seeking police protection would have put them at risk; no nexus to protected grounds under s. 96
Credibility_Assessment: RPD found applicants failed to establish credibility regarding state protection unavailability
Decision_Outcome: RPD concluded state protection was available in Mexico
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed
Relief_Sought: Recognition as refugees and protection under IRPA
Remedy_Sought: Overturning of RPD's rejection of refugee claim
Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution under s. 96 IRPA
Decision_Rationale: RPD's decision was justified, transparent, and intelligible; applicants did not meet burden of proof to show state protection unavailable

Crimes.Crime_Name: Making untrue statements in Personal Information Form
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Was the Board's decision to find the applicant not credible reasonable under the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act?
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Contradictions between testimony and Personal Information Form, implausible elements in story, inconsistencies in documents
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: Applicant failed to provide credible evidence supporting claim
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Credibility findings reviewed on reasonableness standard with margin of appreciation
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Persecution due to alleged anti-revolutionary activities
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Claim not well-founded due to lack of credibility
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Personal Information Form, testimony, submitted documents
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Personal Information Form, oral testimony, documentary evidence
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Subsection 72(1), Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Authority: Immigration and Refugee Board, Federal Court

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Challenge to credibility based on document alterations

Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Asylum claim involving altered evidence
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Manual alterations in official documents
Crimes.Application_Factor: Authenticity and reliability of submitted documents

Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Claim dismissed due to lack of credibility
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Testimony, video-related claims, written records

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Asylum claim involving illegal economic conduct
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Did the Board unreasonably find the applicant lacked credibility?
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Contradictions in story, including implausible activities and document inconsistencies
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: Applicant failed to demonstrate well-founded claim
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Credibility findings subject to reasonableness review
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Claim dismissed due to lack of credible evidence
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Oral testimony, documentary evidence
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Subsection 72(1), Immigration and Refugee Protection Act

Violation_Type: Failure to meet residency requirement for citizenship
Legal_Provision_Violated: Residency requirement under the Citizenship Act, R.S.C. 1985, c. C-29
Application_Facts: Applicant's passive indicators of residence, low income, medical visits, tenancy agreements, and laser treatment schedule were considered by the judge
Residency_Compliance: Disputed – judge questioned sufficiency of evidence
Procedural_Issue: Citizenship Judge failed to address key concerns with applicant during interview
Evidence_Used: Passive indicators of residence, income level, medical records, tenancy agreements, laser treatment schedule
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of direct contradictions in evidence; insufficient probing of applicant on residency indicators
Credibility_Assessment: Judge questioned credibility based on indirect factors without adequate justification
Decision_Outcome: Citizenship application denied due to perceived insufficient evidence of residency
Outcome: Appeal allowed
Legal_Standard_Applied: Residency requirement for citizenship under the Citizenship Act
Decision_Rationale: Judge's decision was unreasonable due to reliance on irrelevant or erroneous reasons and failure to properly assess residency evidence

Application_Facts: Mr. Sadek and Ms. Barakhe were absent from Canada for work but maintained Canadian homes, tax obligations, and family ties
Residency_Compliance: 1095 days physical residency required; absences deemed temporary with maintained ties
Procedural_Issue: Minister challenged Citizenship Judge's interpretation of residency requirements
Evidence_Used: Canadian homes, tax filings, family ties, employment-related absence details
Credibility_Assessment: Absences found to be temporary and reasonable by Citizenship Judge
Outcome: Mr. Sadek and Ms. Barakhe granted citizenship
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of Citizenship Judge's decision
Remedy_Sought: Overturning of citizenship grant based on residency grounds
Decision_Rationale: The Citizenship Judge correctly applied the 'roots' test and concluded absences were temporary with strong ties maintained to Canada

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) and Regulations
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant sought a three-year employment authorization but was perceived to intend to remain in Canada permanently
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Found non-compliant due to lack of demonstrated temporary intent
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Alleged failure to inform applicant of concerns and delegation of interview process
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Documentation and statements indicating intent to stay permanently
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient proof of temporary intent and ties to home country
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Credibility questioned regarding stated purpose of stay
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Concerns arose directly from applicable immigration laws; procedural fairness not violated

Crimes.Crime_Name: Work Permit Fraud under Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Immigration inadmissibility based on alleged membership in a criminal organization

Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness standard applied to administrative decision
Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Breach: No finding of breach; process deemed fair

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Immigration inadmissibility based on suspected membership in a criminal organization

Crimes.Basis_for_Decision: Credibility assessment and reliance on confidential evidence

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Civil/Contempt
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Did Paul Chun commit contempt of court by knowingly violating an Anton Piller order prohibiting the sale of counterfeit Louis Vuitton products?
Crimes.Governing_Law: Contempt of court law, trademark protection statutes
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Evidence showed sales at a night market in September 2000 and from his van in August 2001; photographs and witness testimonies were presented
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Chun acknowledged the order and shrugged when confronted, indicating awareness and lack of remorse
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Contempt of court occurs when a person disobeys a court order, proven beyond a reasonable doubt, requiring knowledge and willful disobedience
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Proof of disobedience to a valid court order with knowledge
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Violation of Anton Piller order prohibiting sale of counterfeit goods
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Chun found guilty of violating the court order twice
Key_Evidence_Considered: Service of Anton Piller order in July 2000
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Federal Court rules on injunctions and contempt
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Acknowledged the order but continued selling; shrugged when confronted
Crimes.Outcome: Fined $50,000 and ordered to pay $35,000 in costs; potential imprisonment if unpaid within 90 days
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Anton Piller order under Federal Court jurisdiction

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Civil Contempt
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Did Paul Chun knowingly disobey a court order prohibiting the sale of counterfeit Louis Vuitton products?
Crimes.Governing_Law: Law of contempt, enforcement of court orders
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Court evaluated testimony and physical evidence of post-order sales
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Chun admitted knowledge of the order but engaged in prohibited conduct
Crimes.Legal_Rule: A person is guilty of contempt if they knowingly disobey a court order. Elements: existence of order, knowledge, and deliberate disobedience
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Clear and convincing evidence of willful violation
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Chun found guilty for two separate violations after the order
Key_Evidence_Considered: Service and acknowledgment of Anton Piller order
Photographic and testimonial proof of distribution
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Admitted awareness but failed to comply; nonchalant attitude upon confrontation
Crimes.Outcome: $50,000 fine and $35,000 in costs; possible 60-day imprisonment if unpaid
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Inherent jurisdiction of court to punish contempt

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Civil Enforcement
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Did Paul Chun commit civil contempt by violating the court order prohibiting him from selling counterfeit Louis Vuitton products?
Crimes.Governing_Law: Trademarks Act, common law contempt principles
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Evidence demonstrated ongoing commercial sale of infringing goods after binding order
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Found in violation of court order (civil contempt)
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: Beyond a reasonable doubt (for criminal contempt); clear and convincing for civil contempt
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Chun confirmed the order was still in effect but disregarded it
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Civil contempt requires: existence of a court order, knowledge by defendant, and knowing disobedience
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Continued sale of counterfeit branded goods post-injunction
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Liability established for repeated infringement activities
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Intellectual property enforcement via equitable remedies
Crimes.Defendant_Response: No defense raised; tacit admission through conduct
Crimes.Outcome: Sanctioned with $50,000 fine and $35,000 costs; subject to incarceration if unpaid
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section of Trademarks Act related to unauthorized use; court’s equitable powers

Violation_Type: Failure to meet physical presence requirement
Application_Facts: Applicant was absent from Canada for 200 days due to caring for her ill mother and business trips
Residency_Compliance: Failed to accumulate 1095 days of residence in Canada over four years
Procedural_Issue: Appeal to the Federal Court after denial by Citizenship Judge
Evidence_Used: Records of absences, humanitarian reasons for travel
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of sufficient evidence to meet physical presence test despite compelling reasons
Outcome: Citizenship application denied
Legal_Standard_Applied: 1095-day physical presence requirement under paragraph 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act
Decision_Rationale: The Citizenship Judge reasonably applied the physical presence test within their discretion; humanitarian reasons did not override statutory requirement
